sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The genusAeromonas resides within the family Aeromonadaceae (1) and the proposed order Aeromonadales ord. nov., along with the genera Oceanimonas and Tolumonas (2). Aeromonas is the only one of these three genera that is pathogenic for humans. The frequent reclassifications and constant amended or extended descriptions within Aeromonas taxonomy have historically been puzzling to many microbiologists. However, most of the controversies have been resolved (3), and recent advances have contributed to a clarified, although more complex, understanding of the genus. Data now clearly show that the genus Aeromonas is organized as a complex of species, i.e., groups of species with unclear boundaries, as observed in Vibrio, Acinetobacter, and several Enterobacterales genera (4).

Among the 36 taxonomic species described in the genus, one-third have been characterized over the past 10 years (2). Importantly, displaying an accurate taxonomy directly helped researchers recognize that the species Aeromonas dhakensis is both more frequent and more virulent than other taxa recovered from humans (5, 6). It was previously reported as an “arabinose-negative” Aeromonas hydrophila-like group of organisms and thus misidentified as A. hydrophila (7–10). The information in this chapter should clarify the identification and significance of the species most often associated with human disease (Table 1). No new Aeromonas species has been proposed since the publication of the previous edition of this Manual.

Clinically significant strains formerly referred to asAeromonas sobria are, in fact, Aeromonas veronii biovar sobria (esculin hydrolysis and ornithine decarboxylase negative and arginine dihydrolase positive) and should be reported as such.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS
sect2.para: Members of the genusAeromonas are Gram-negative facultative anaerobes that are straight, coccobacillary to bacillary cells with rounded ends (0.3 to 1.0 μm in diameter and 1.0 to 3.5 μm in length). They can occur singly, in pairs, or rarely in short chains. Most species are motile by a single, polar flagellum with a 1.7-μm wavelength, but uniformly distributed flagella may be formed on solid media in young cultures, and lateral flagella may occur. Aeromonads are usually oxidase positive and catalase positive and are generally resistant to 150 μg of the vibriostatic agent 2,4-diamino-6,7-diisopropylpteridine (O/129) (2).

Members of the genusAeromonas are characterized by large metabolic capabilities and a strong ability to quickly colonize a variety of niches and hosts (11). They are chemoorganotrophic, displaying oxidative and fermentative metabolism of glucose. Acid, and often acid with gas, is produced from many carbohydrates, especially glucose, and nitrate is reduced to nitrite. A variety of exoenzymes, such as arylamidases, amylase, DNase, esterases, peptidases, proteases, chitinase, chondroitinase, and hemolysins, are produced. The main cellular fatty acids produced are hexadecanoic acid (16:0), hexadecenoic acid (16:1), and octadecenoic acid (18:1). Human (mesophilic) strains grow between 10 and 42°C, but occasional isolates may be more active in some biochemical assays at 22 to 25°C. Psychrophilic strains from fish and the environment (Aeromonas popoffii and Aeromonas salmonicida) seldom grow above 37°C and preferentially grow at 22 to 25°C. In brain heart infusion broth at 28°C, growth occurs between pH 4.5 and 9.0 and at salt concentrations between 0 and 4%. The genome sizes estimated from the draft genomes range from 3.90 Mbp (Aeromonas fluvialisT) to 5.18 Mbp (Aeromonas piscicolaT), with an average of 4.51 Mbp. The G+C content of the DNA is 57 to 63 mol% (2, 3).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Aeromonads are inhabitants of aquatic ecosystems, such as groundwater, reservoirs, clean or polluted lakes and rivers, and mud, worldwide.Aeromonas species may also be found in marine environments but only in brackish water or water with a low saline content. Most Aeromonas species, particularly those associated with human infections, are found in a wide variety of fresh produce, meat (e.g., beef, poultry, and pork), dairy products (e.g., raw milk and raw ice cream) (11), and drinking water (12–14). A. veronii biovar sobria is the major symbiont in the gut of medicinal leeches, such that Aeromonas species is associated with nosocomial zoonosis when infection complicates leech therapy (15). However, it should be noted that most of these infections are caused by A. hydrophila, likely because it is more virulent, even though it is present at a low density in the leech crop. Aeromonas also colonizes the mouths of snakes, with related infections following snake bites. Infections in frogs, pigs, cattle, birds, and marine animals have also been reported (11).

table.title: TABLE 1 Members of the genus Aeromonasa

entry.phrase: Pathogenic for animals, fish, and reptiles

sect2.para: aDNA hybridization group numbers, which no longer serve a meaningful purpose, synonymous species designations for Aeromonas veronii biovar sobria (Aeromonas ichthiosmia, Aeromonas culicicola) (102) and Aeromonas trota (Aeromonas enteropelogenes) (101, 103, 104, 105), and Aeromonas sp. DNA hybridization group 11, which is made up of Aeromonas eucrenophila/Aeromonas encheleia-like organisms, are not included for simplicity. NA, not applicable.
bA. dhakensis was formerly known as A. hydrophila subsp. dhakensis and A. aquariorum sp. nov. (8).

cThere are motile strains of A. salmonicida that grow at 37°C and resemble clinical A. hydrophila strains that have been isolated from human feces; these can be distinguished using the tests in Table 3.

Most clinical infections with aeromonads are related to an exposure to some type of aquatic source, whether the clinical specimen is feces or extraintestinal, and to a lesser extent to the ingestion of foods. Evidence of water-to-human transmission has been established (14). Most studies have found a seasonal relationship between the recovery of aeromonads from specimens and the warmer months of the year (16). The optimal temperatures for growth of mesophilic aeromonads are those occurring in the warmer months. This therefore increases the likelihood of recreational human exposure to these bacteria, thereby resulting in an increased risk of colonization and/or infections with these indigenous aquatic microorganisms.

SinceAeromonas infections are not a reportable condition in the United States or in most other countries, the true incidence worldwide is not known. Estimates from England/Wales and the United States for septicemia with aeromonads in 2004 revealed an incidence of 1.5 per million population (11). However, any estimates of incidence would most likely be an underestimation.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Aeromonas species are environmental opportunistic pathogens, involved in numerous types of diseases, including gastroenteritis and infections at a variety of extraintestinal sites, of which blood and wounds are the most common. The most frequent species recovered from human infections are A. caviae, A. dhakensis, A. hydrophila, and A. veronii biovar sobria, accounting for >90% (5, 11). No major change in the epidemiology of aeromonosis has been reported since the publication of the previous edition of this Manual, and no new knowledge in this field adds to what has been previously described.

sect1.title: Gastroenteritis
sect1.para: The role ofAeromonas species in gastroenteritis has been questioned because volunteers challenged with a high dose of Aeromonas species did not develop symptoms of enteric illness (17) and because of the low number of reported outbreaks. Beyond the numerous data that focus on the association of Aeromonas species with diarrhea (summarized in reference 18), a study reassessed the enteropathogenicity of Aeromonas species using a dose response model for microbial infection and acute illness and confirmed the enteropathogenicity of Aeromonas species (18).

Aeromonas gastroenteritis ranges from an acute watery diarrhea (most common form) to dysenteric illness and to chronic illness. Stools from acute watery diarrhea are loose (i.e., they take the shape of their container), and erythrocytes and fecal leukocytes are absent. Accompanying symptoms include abdominal pain (60 to 70% of patients), fever and vomiting (20 to 50%), and nausea (40%) (11, 19). In cases of dysenteric diarrhea resembling shigellosis, patients suffer from severe abdominal pain and have bloody stools containing mucus and polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Although most diarrheal cases are generally self-limited, a combination of supportive therapy and antimicrobials is often indicated in pediatric, geriatric, and immunocompromised populations (11). Management of aeromonad-caused gastroenteritis follows the rules of diarrhea management in general.

A. caviae is the most common species associated with these infections, followed by A. veronii biovar sobria. A large study in India found seven species among hospitalized patients with diarrhea, with A. caviae predominating, followed by A. hydrophila and A. veronii biovar sobria (20). In a large acute diarrheal outbreak in Brazil that involved 2,170 cases, Aeromonas was the genus recovered in 19.5% of cases (21). A large study of traveler’s diarrhea in Spain found that Aeromonas accounted for 2% of traveler’s diarrhea, with the predominant species being A. veronii biovar sobria and A. caviae (19). A. caviae infection can even mimic inflammatory bowel disease in children (22). A. veronii biovar sobria strains may be associated with a rare cholera-like disease characterized by abdominal pain (60%) and fever and nausea (20%) (23).

About 10 to 15% of patients with either cholera-like or dysenteric diarrhea are coinfected with another enteric pathogen(s). Aeromonad pathogenicity remains poorly understood, and the data may be confounded by the accuracy of the tools used or the study designs.

Complications fromAeromonas diarrheal disease include hemolytic-uremic syndrome (24, 25), kidney disease requiring kidney transplantation, and colitis (11, 26). These more severe infections are usually associated with A. hydrophila or A. veronii biovar sobria. In addition, nonresolvable, intermittent diarrhea can occur months after the initial infection and may persist for months or several years. Some episodes are linked to foreign travel prior to the onset of disease, but risk factors or comorbidities associated with chronic diarrhea are unknown, as is the frequency of chronic diarrhea due to Aeromonas (11).

sect1.title: Extraintestinal Infections
sect1.para: Aeromonas septicemia occurs rarely in immunocompetent hosts; most cases occur in patients with liver disease, diabetes mellitus, or hematological malignancies and can be accompanied by necrotizing fasciitis (27, 28). Aeromonas bacteremia is also reported in patients with no comorbidity who are either pregnant (29) or elderly (30, 31). The source of bacteremia is most frequently the gut (through translocation), hepatobiliary disease or peritonitis, or, rarely, an infected wound. The species isolated from patients with septicemia are A. caviae, A. veronii biovar sobria, A. dhakensis, and A. hydrophila; polymicrobial cultures are frequent (30%) (30).

Wound infections are usually preceded by a traumatic injury (even an insignificant one) that occurs in contact with water. The predominant species areA. dhakensis (formerly A. aquariorum), A. veronii, and A. hydrophila. These infections range from uncomplicated cases of cellulitis to myonecrotic infections and necrotizing fasciitis with a poor prognosis (32, 33). Scenarios of such infection are as follows: (i) sporadic wound infections following recreational or occupational activities or following severe trauma (e.g., car crash injuries), (ii) outbreaks of wound infections associated with mud football (34), (iii) wound infections following natural disasters (e.g., in tsunami survivors [35], hurricane survivors [36], and earthquake survivors [37]), and (iv) use of medicinal leeches postoperatively to enhance blood flow to surgical sites, which results in wound infection rates between 4.1 and 36.2%, primarily with A. veronii biovar sobria or A. hydrophila (14, 38). Most alarming is the ongoing number of reports of ciprofloxacin-resistant Aeromonas strains in patients after receiving leech therapy (39–42). Surveys have indicated that only 17 to 52% of Aeromonas wound infections are monomicrobic (11, 30), and the polymicrobial infections may contribute to more severe clinical presentations (43, 44).

Intra-abdominal infections include (i) cholecystitis and cholangitis that occur in patients with compression due to gallstones or cancer (mortality rate, 0 to 10%), (ii) pancreatic abscesses, and (iii) spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (mortality rate, 20 to 56%). These infections are frequently associated with bacteremia. Other extraintestinal infections include ocular infections, such as keratitis associated with contact lenses, respiratory and urinary tract infections, meningitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, pneumonia, endocarditis, portal pyemia, surgical site infections, and spa bath folliculitis (45–56).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Aeromonads survive well in specimens, and any of the widely used transport media are acceptable for transport (Amies, Cary-Blair, modified Stuart’s, and buffered glycerol in saline), with Cary-Blair generally considered to be the best for feces transportation (seechapter 19). Feces are preferable to rectal swabs for isolation of enteric pathogens; stools should be collected in the acute phase of disease. Most strains grow equally well at room temperature (20 to 25°C) and incubator temperature (35 to 37°C). Because isolates being kept for long-term storage do not survive well at room or refrigerator temperature in the laboratory for long periods (>1 month), placing aeromonads in medium, such as Trypticase soy broth with 30% glycerol, and deep-freezing them at −80°C is recommended for long-term storage.

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: The direct microscopic examination of wound or skin/superficial specimens or positive blood culture specimens is somewhat unremarkable in that aeromonads appear as straight, Gram-negative bacilli, with or without the presence of white cells, which is not unlike the presentation of a similar infection with either enterics or pseudomonads.

Although various DNA probe and multiplex PCR methods have been described for the identification of aeromonads (specifically, identification of genes for enterotoxins) from either water, food, or veterinary sources, there are no widely recognized antigen detection and/or nucleic acid detection methods available for accurate detection of pathogenic strains from clinical specimens.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Aeromonads generally grow well on a variety of enteric differential and selective agars, although sucrose- and/or lactose-fermenting strains usually resemble nonpathogens on these media. Blood agar with 20 μg of ampicillin per ml was previously considered useful for isolatingAeromonas species; however, a small proportion of aeromonads are susceptible to ampicillin, and certain species, such as Aeromonas trota, are intrinsically susceptible to ampicillin (57, 58). An environmental sampling study to detect aeromonads showed that when ampicillin is used as a selective agent, a significant portion (17.3%) of the aeromonad population, in at least some environments, cannot be isolated using such media (59). Therefore, laboratories should use caution when a medium with ampicillin is used in the setup of stool specimens for detecting the presence of all clinically relevant Aeromonas species as bacterial enteropathogens.

Modified cefsulodin-irgasan-novobiocin (CIN) (4 μg of cefsulodin per ml, versus 15 μg/ml in unmodified CIN) is an excellent isolation medium for aeromonads. On this medium,Aeromonas colonies have a pink center with an uneven, clear apron and are morphologically indistinguishable from Yersinia enterocolitica. One can incubate CIN at 25°C to enhance the recovery of Yersinia cells and still be able to recover Aeromonas species within 24 h at this temperature. Aeromonas agar, available from Lab-M, is an alternative to CIN agar and uses D-xylose (which aeromonads do not ferment) as a differential characteristic (60).

Since most clinically relevant species are β-hemolytic, including an increasing number ofA. caviae strains, β-hemolytic colonies on blood agar should be screened either with matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) or oxidase and a spot indole test. Any colonies that are positive by both tests should be characterized further, although occasional indole-negative A. caviae strains do occur, and nearly all known Aeromonas schubertii isolates (which are generally but rarely associated with severe aquatic wounds) are indole negative (61). Thiosulfate citrate bile salts-sucrose medium is usually inhibitory to aeromonads. Enrichment in alkaline peptone water enhances the recovery of Aeromonas spp. from stools from populations that are generally expected to shed low numbers of organisms (carriers, convalescent-phase patients, and those with subclinical infections). For patients with acute diarrhea, however, enrichment is unnecessary (62). Several reports have highlighted infections involving two different aeromonads (5 to 10% of cases) that may result in a more severe disease (43, 44, 63). This justifies the search for several species within a culture in case of severe disease, noting that a given isolate may also present varying characteristics.

sect2.title: RAPID DETECTION FROM SAMPLES
sect2.para: Rapid multiplex PCR methods are now implemented in clinical laboratories. They have allowed significant improvements in the etiological diagnosis of gastroenteritis. Numerous methods/systems are now available and others are being developed. At present, aeromonads are only rarely included in the panel of microbes detected by these systems (64–66). When they are, aeromonads are identified to the genus level. Notably, systems are poorly evaluated for their performance in detecting Aeromonas spp. AllPlex GI Bacteria is currently the only system that detects Aeromonas spp. to have undergone clinical evaluation. Overall performance is satisfactory (sensitivity, 81 to 99%; specificity, 99%). However, aeromonads represent an important proportion of discrepant results (positive culture, negative test result) (64–67). Studies are rare and low powered and do not specify which species are detected or missed. For instance, a study by Martin et al. (65) showed that 13 of 16 stool samples positive for Aeromonas were detected, with 4 discrepant results. In a recent meta-analysis evaluating how these systems perform for gastroenteritis diagnosis, the authors did not discuss the impact of presence/absence of aeromonads in the panels (66).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) is the reference method to identify aeromonads or to describe a novel species. Methods based on nucleic acid testing, namely, WGS and housekeeping gene sequencing with phylogenetic analysis from pure cultures, are the most accurate methods for identifying aeromonads to the species level. If possible, these methods should be performed whenever identification to the species level is needed. Conventional biochemical systems and 16S rRNA sequencing have the lowest performance, even when additional testing is used, which requires a long time to obtain results with a poor workflow and the least updated databases. MALDI-TOF MS shows the best ratio of quality to time to result, but performance differs between systems, and databases must be improved (see “Identification to the Species Level”) (68).

sect1.title: Identification to the Genus Level
sect1.para: Aeromonads are glucose-fermenting, oxidase-positive, motile, Gram-negative rods that are resistant to O/129. Nucleic acid amplification testing methods based either on 16S ribosomal RNA gene or housekeeping gene sequencing, WGS, and MALDI-TOF MS have excellent performance for identifying aeromonads to the genus level (69, 70). Conventional biochemical methods are also excellent, but there are some pitfalls. Aeromonas species are most easily confused with Vibrio and Plesiomonas species. Plesiomonas species are easily differentiated from Aeromonas species by positive reactions in Moeller’s lysine, ornithine, and arginine tests and by fermentation of m-inositol. Vibrios may be more difficult to distinguish from aeromonads, which is particularly true for Vibrio fluvialis and A. caviae, especially in laboratories where the sole means of identification is a commercial phenotypic system (e.g., the API-20-E strip [bioMérieux, Inc.] and the NFC47 panel with a MicroScan Walk/Away system [Beckman Coulter, Inc.]) (71–73). Resistance to an O/129 vibriostatic agent (150 μg), string test negativity (with 0.5% sodium desoxycholate), and the inability to grow in salt concentrations of ≥6% usually indicate the genus Aeromonas. Vibrio cholerae O139, a cholera toxin-positive, non-salt-requiring, O/129 vibriostatic-agent-resistant species, is a major exception to this rule. However, the decarboxylase pattern (positive for lysine and ornithine), negative reaction for arginine dihydrolase, no production of gas from glucose, and no fermentation of salicin distinguish this organism from most aeromonads. Unfortunately, strains of ornithine decarboxylase-positive A. veronii biovar veronii often yield an excellent to very good identification for V. cholerae with the rapid identification API-20-E strip, making serotyping and/or additional testing required to resolve the issue. A. veronii biovar veronii is string test negative, O/129 resistant, and able to produce gas from glucose fermentation, does not require additional salt for growth, and is inhibited on thiosulfate citrate bile salts-sucrose agar. V. cholerae has the opposite reactions.

sect1.title: Identification to the Species Level
sect1.para: Sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA gene (74) shows disappointing performance in identifying aeromonads to the species level. This is because of the frequent intragenomic heterogeneity within the 16S ribosomal RNA gene in Aeromonas species; caution is required when using this single gene for anything beyond genus-level identification, because the interspecies variability is between 0 and 5% (75, 76). The use of other housekeeping genes as molecular markers, such as gyrB and rpoD, dnaJ, and rpoB and cpn60, or an even broader approach, such as multilocus phylogenetic analysis, is advised because of higher resolving power (77–80). Compared to the 16S rRNA gene, these genes offer two advantages: they exhibit higher diversity that enables differentiation between species, and they are present in a single copy, which eliminates the risk of intragenomic diversity. For instance, a 1.1-kb gyrB sequence exhibits a <2.6% intraspecies diversity and a >3% interspecies diversity for most species (81). Any of the aforementioned genes is accurate to identify aeromonads to the species level; the most widely used is gyrB (>5,800 NCBI entries in 2022). Incorrect identifications are related to horizontal gene transfer, reported at a frequency up to 2% according to the tested gene (69). As a consequence, identification results should be confirmed with at least another sequenced gene or, optimally, a multilocus phylogeny analysis (e.g., for publications of case reports or epidemiological studies).

MALDI-TOF MS was first described forAeromonas species identification in 2007 (82), with further validation in 2011 (70), and resulted in a 2012 rapid MALDI-TOF MS Aeromonas database for clinical and environmental isolates (83). So far, two FDA-cleared systems, the Biotyper system (Bruker, Inc.) and Vitek MS (bioMérieux, Inc.), are available, with differing database content. Some limitations are recognized. Databases from both systems are incomplete: of the 36 species of the genus, 20 and 26 are missing in the Biotyper and in the Vitek MS systems, respectively, and of the 16 species recovered from human infections, 7 and 9 are missing, respectively. Importantly, A. dhakensis is absent from both systems.

The Biotyper system has been extensively evaluated for aeromonad identification performance.A. dhakensis is wrongly identified as A. hydrophila or Aeromonas jandaei (84). Isolates belonging to species absent from the database are often misidentified with a tricky high-level score likely because species are closely related. An overview of how isolates from unrepresented species are misidentified by the Biotyper system is available (85). In addition, relatively low discriminatory power between taxa is recognized, characterized by small score differences that also reflect species closeness (70, 83, 84). When the first two matches are different, identification should be checked with an extraction procedure. When the issue persists, the first match corresponds to accurate identification in 80% of the cases (85). Despite these limitations, the overall accuracy of the Biotyper system approaches 90% when the epidemiology observed in temperate countries is taken into consideration (70, 83) but is expected to be lower in warm areas where A. dhakensis is frequent.

To date, the Vitek MS has not been evaluated for members of the genusAeromonas, but its performance in identifying isolates to the species level is expected to be disappointing given the database content and because the manufacturer acknowledges that the system currently (i) does not properly discriminate A. caviae from A. hydrophila and (ii) frequently fails to identify A. veronii.

The default of accuracy is mostly related to the default of database content. Spectra generated for aeromonads exhibit specific peaks useful for identifying isolates to the species level. For instance, the Biotyper system can accurately identifyA. dhakensis because of specific peaks (68). Defaults in databases can be overcome by using an in-house database. However, in-house databases may be tedious to develop and to validate, so users should take this point into account before adopting this strategy. The databases from both systems should be updated to at least include the most recently defined species involved in human disease, e.g., A. dhakensis and Aeromonas sanarelli.

Biochemical methods have the longest time to result and the lowest performance. After an aeromonad is identified, a small number of biochemical tests can be used to affiliate the isolate with one of the three major species complexes (Table 2). If warranted, even more discriminatory results for separating members of each complex can be found in bold text in Table 3 (61), which should replace earlier published results for species identification. However, most of these tests are not performed since the introduction of MALDI-TOF MS in clinical laboratories. A comparison study on the accuracy of six commercial systems for identifying 87 clinical Aeromonas isolates to the correct species level highlighted outdated databases and taxonomy, weak algorithms, and impractical tests, with 67.8 to 91.9% accuracy (73). The same study reported the ability to accurately identify 95.5% of the 87 clinical isolates to the species level using the seven conventional phenotypic tests within the simple dichotomous key, Aerokey II (84). A. dhakensis is distinguished from A. hydrophila by its ability to utilize urocanic acid and its inability to produce acid from L-arabinose. This key is reliable for clinical strains only.

table.title: TABLE 2 Biochemical identification of Aeromonas to the complex level

entry.phrase: % of strains identified as belonging toa:
A. hydrophila complex (A. hydrophila, A. dhakensis, A. bestiarum, A. salmonicida)
A. caviae complex (A. caviae, A. media, A. eucrenophila)
A. veronii complex (A. veronii HG8,b A. jandaei, A. schubertii, A. trota)

sect1.para: aThe first number is the overall percentage of strains that were positive for each complex for a given trait; the numbers in parentheses are percentages of strains positive for each species listed within that complex. Data are derived and modified from Table 5 in reference 61 and from reference 7.

bA. veronii biovar sobria (DNA hybridization group 8). The separation of A. veronii biovar veronii (DNA hybridization group 10) from A. veronii biovar sobria is achieved with A. veronii biovar veronii having positive reactions for ornithine decarboxylase and esculin hydrolysis and a negative reaction for arginine dihydrolase.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Historical reliable methods for typing aeromonads included pulsed-field gel electrophoresis using XbaI, SwaI, or SpeI, followed by PCR-based techniques, including enterobacterial repetitive intergenic consensus sequence PCR (ERIC-PCR), BOX element PCR, repetitive extragenic palindromic PCR (REP-PCR), and methods combining several types of repetitive elements (e.g., ERIC and REP). A 2015 expanded review summarizes the available data (86). These methods have now been replaced by WGS.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Serologic assays that have been used to detect antibodies toAeromonas species (tube agglutination, immunoblotting, and enzyme-linked immunoassay) have low sensitivity and specificity and are not considered reliable.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: A general antimicrobial susceptibility profile forAeromonas derived from several investigations that included only strains that are well characterized at the species level (87–90) is given in Table 4. Aeromonas species can express three chromosomal β-lactam-induced β-lactamases, including a group 1 molecular class C cephalosporinase, a group 2d molecular class D penicillinase (oxacillinase), and a group 3 molecular class B metallo-β-lactamase (carbapenemase). The distribution of these genes is species specific (e.g., CphA metallo-β lactamase is present in A. hydrophila, A. dhakensis, and A. veronii but not in A. caviae [Table 4]) (91). Further, the presence of these β-lactamases in Aeromonas species, particularly carbapenemase, may not be detected by conventional susceptibility methods (92).

Strains show a propensity to acquire resistance genes and to disseminate them to other bacteria. This is important because aeromonads are at the interface of the environment, animal, and human compartments of One Health. For this reason, they have recently earned the nickname of “middleman” (93). Strains that are resistant to expanded-spectrum cephalosporins by the production of acquired extended-spectrum β-lactamases are occasionally reported from clinical specimens in a context of carriage or infection and from water sources (94–96). More recently, A. caviae strains carrying either New Delhi metallo-β-lactamase 1 on the chromosome or Verona integron-encoded metallo-β-lactamase 1 on mobile elements (plasmids or integrons) have been isolated from various parts of the world from both clinical specimens and aquatic environments (96–98). This warrants concern among physicians because of the possible emergence of multidrug resistance within this genus, the spread via water or sewage systems, and the potential for dissemination to clinically important Gram-negative pathogens (92, 94, 95, 97). The complexity of β-lactamases among clinical Aeromonas isolates can result in resistance to a broad spectrum of β-lactams. Thus, both conventional in vitro susceptibility testing and, in selected cases, additional testing for extended-spectrum β-lactamases and carbapenemase production are suggested (99).

Ciprofloxacin, which is commonly used to treat infections with Gram-negative organisms, was initially reported as active against all species ofAeromonas, with little or no resistance reported in studies in the United States and most of Europe (30, 87, 88, 100). However, 2 to 3% of A. caviae, A. hydrophila, and A. veronii biovar sobria strains in Asia were reported to be ciprofloxacin resistant as early as 1996 (89). As mentioned above, there are increasing reports of ciprofloxacin-resistant infections following leech therapy. Because ciprofloxacin is recommended for prophylaxis, these recurrent reports warrant both caution and the revision of prevention strategies until the source of ciprofloxacin-resistant strains is controlled (e.g., as noted in references 39–42). Susceptibilities to other antimicrobial agents (e.g., aminoglycosides, tetracycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) may differ from one geographic area to another. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing of local isolates is necessary because of emerging resistance. There are Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute testing guidelines for the major clinical Aeromonas species that relate to dilution and disk susceptibility testing in document M45-A2 for infrequently isolated or fastidious bacteria (101).

table.title: TABLE 3 Tests useful in the separation of members within the Aeromonas species complexes

sect2.para: aData were compiled from Tables 2, 6, 7, and 8 in reference 61 and from reference 7. +, ≥85% of the strains were positive; −, <15% were positive; V, 15 to 85% were positive (results at 48 h). Numbers in parentheses indicate percentages of strains positive for the test at the final day of reading, which for gluconate was 2 days; for DL-lactate and urocanic acid, 3 days; for citrate, 4 days; for carbohydrates, indole, and lipase, 7 days; for pyrazinamidase (PZA), 2 days; for Ampr (resistance to 10 μg of ampicillin), 1 day; for Voges-Proskauer, 3 days. ND, not done. For each of the three Aeromonas species complexes, the discriminatory reactions between the species within each complex are presented in bold type.

bIn addition, A. dhakensis (formerly known as A. hydrophila subsp. dhakensis and A. aquariorum sp. nov.) is considered to have positive reactions in the esculin tests but negative reactions for utilization of L-arabinose and L-fucose, negative fermentation of L-arabinose, and positive utilization of urocanic acid (7).

cA. veronii biovar sobria (DNA hybridization group 8). The separation of A. veronii biovar veronii (DNA hybridization group 10) from A. veronii biovar sobria is achieved by A. veronii biovar veronii having positive reactions for ornithine decarboxylase and esculin hydrolysis and a negative reaction for arginine dihydrolase.

table.title: TABLE 4 Type of β-lactamase expressed by Aeromonas species and corresponding antimicrobial susceptibility profile to β-lactams

sect2.para: aData compiled from references 11, 91, 93, and 98.
bR, resistant; S, susceptible (≥90% of all isolates are resistant or susceptible); V, variable (10 to 90% of isolates are susceptible).
cThe cephalosporinase gene is present in the genome but is not expressed.
dCarbapenemase expression is usually weak (low level) and may not be detected by conventional methods.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Intestinal aeromonad isolates can be identified as belonging either to theA. hydrophila or A. caviae complex or to the A. veronii complex and not “A. sobria,” which is now A. veronii biovar sobria, a member of the A. veronii complex. For routine isolates recovered from uncomplicated cases of gastroenteritis, this level of identification may be sufficient. Although there is very strong evidence that some aeromonads are gastrointestinal pathogens, there is no convincing evidence, at present, that all fecal isolates of Aeromonas species are involved in diarrheal disease, since <1 to 4% of people are asymptomatic carriers (11). Thus, the significance of the recovery of aeromonads from stool specimens should be interpreted cautiously and must rely on both laboratory information and clinical interpretation. Because of this, the relative quantity of Aeromonas organisms recovered on enteric media (few colonies, moderate growth, or predominant organism) might be reported in conjunction with the Aeromonas complex or species identification. For complicated cases of diarrhea, e.g., prolonged bloody diarrhea in pediatric patients or chronic gastroenteritis of >1 month’s duration or in cancer patients with positive fecal cultures (in whom Aeromonas species tend to disseminate), definitive species identification may be warranted.

For extraintestinal isolates (e.g., from blood or wounds), the same general rules should apply as to species identification of intestinal aeromonads. Although both thein vitro and in vivo pathogenic potentials of Aeromonas species and strains vary considerably, there are no universal markers or indicators that dictate when isolates should be definitively identified to the species level. However, future studies should identify isolates to the species level, because some more virulent species can now be recognized (A. dhakensis) by using fast and accurate methods. Identifying aeromonads at the species level should be considered at least (i) for isolates isolated from sterile body sites (e.g., blood and cerebrospinal fluid) and serious wound infections (cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis), (ii) for isolates exhibiting unusual resistance patterns or associated with nosocomial infection, and (iii) for publications describing traditional species or newly described species isolated from new anatomic sites.
